summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys (Cohen & Gresser LLP) to the government prosecutors, complaining about ongoing discovery violations. The letter details repeated failures to provide readable discovery materials to Maxwell in the MDC, specifically mentioning unreadable files and thousands of seized images from Jeffrey Epstein's residences that Maxwell cannot access.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, currently detained at the MDC. The letter is about the government's failure to provide her with readable discovery materials.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His residences in New York and the Virgin Islands were searched, resulting in the seizure of approximately 40,000 non-nude and thousands of nude/partially nude images that are part of the discovery materials.

connections.description: The document references images seized from Epstein's residences that are part of the discovery in Maxwell's case, indicating a close association central to the investigation.

events.title: Court-ordered discovery deadline
events.description: The deadline set by the court for the government to provide discovery materials to the defense, which the government had not met as of the date of this letter.

events.title: Discovery issues conference call
events.description: A conference call between defense counsel and government prosecutors to discuss problems with unreadable discovery files provided to Maxwell at the MDC.

events.title: Follow-up discovery conference call
events.description: Another conference call to discuss ongoing discovery problems, including access to seized images and the government's failure to provide readable materials.

keyFacts: The government had failed for over five weeks to provide Ghislaine Maxwell with a complete, readable set of discovery materials by the October 1, 2020 deadline.
Approximately 40,000 non-nude photographs and thousands of nude/partially nude images were seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the Virgin Islands and were part of the discovery.
COVID-19 restrictions prevented the U.S. Marshals from producing pretrial detainees to proffer rooms, complicating Maxwell's access to 'Highly Confidential' documents.
The defense requested the government provide a verified, readable laptop with the complete discovery to Maxwell in the MDC, rather than relying on the defense to correct the government's errors.
This letter represents at least the third formal complaint from the defense about discovery issues, following letters dated August 27, 2020, and September 21, 2020.
